affiliation.orgName: Key Laboratory of Transient Optics and Photonics
Xi'an Institute of Optics and Precision Mechanics

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Abstract-Band selection, as a special case of the feature selection problem, tries to remove redundant bands and select a few important bands to represent the whole image cube. This has attracted much attention since the selected bands provide discriminative information for further applications and reduce the computational burden. Though hyperspectral band selection has gained rapid development in recent years, it is still a challenging task because of the following requirements: 1) An effective model can capture the underlying relations between different high-dimensional spectral bands. 2) A fast and robust measure function can adapt to general hyperspectral tasks. 3) An efficient search strategy can find the desired selected bands in reasonable computational time. To satisfy these requirements, a multigraph determinantal point process (MDPP) model is proposed to capture the full structure between different bands and efficiently find the optimal band subset in extensive hyperspectral applications. There are three main contributions: 1) Graphical model is naturally transferred to address band selection problem by the proposed MDPP. 2) Multiple graphs are designed to capture the intrinsic relationships between hyperspectral bands. 3) Mixture determinantal point process (Mix-DPP) is proposed to model the multiple dependencies in the proposed multiple graphs, and offers an efficient search strategy to select the optimal bands. To verify the superiority of the proposed method, experiments have been conducted on three hyperspectral applications, such as hyperspectral classification, anomaly detection, and target detection. The reliability of the proposed method in generic hyperspectral tasks is experimentally proved on four real-world hyperspectral data sets.
Index Terms-Hyperspectral band selection, multiple graphs, determinantal point process, hyperspectral image classification, anomaly detection, target detection.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: T HE increasing availability of hyperspectral images (HSIs) has obtained a significant success in the field of remote sensing [1], [2], [3], [4], [5], [6]. As a data cube, HSI is a set of 2-dimensional images (or spectral bands) and each image represents the reflectance or radiance of a scene in different electromagnetic wavelengths. The increased number of spectral bands provides an explicit and flexible observation of the scene, but that does not mean that all the bands take the role. The most critical factor might be only a few bands. The enormous spectral bands of HSIs provide large volume and redundant information, further cause a big increase in the computational time and make the analysis of HSIs become a fairly complicated task [7], [8], [9], [10]. As a result, band selection is becoming increasingly valuable in practical applications, such as image classification [11], [12], [13] and target detection [14], [15], [16], [17], [18].

Hyperspectral band selection is a feature selection technique [19], [20], [21], [22], [23], [24] that automatically removes the highly correlated bands and selects only a few bands with discriminative information to represent the whole image cube. Though band selection has gained rapid development in recent years, it is still a challenging task and extensive works are needed to improve the performance of selected bands.

Band selection generally includes two procedures: selection criterion and search strategy. The former is to define an appropriate measure function that assigns a score for a band subset from original bands. While the latter is to develop an effective strategy that can find the optimal (in a sense of optimizing the value of the measure function) subset of bands among all feasible subsets.

According to whether the priori information of the class label is required, the traditional methods to address these two procedures can roughly be classified into three groups: supervised [25], [26], [27], semi-supervised [28], [29], and unsupervised methods [30], [31], [32]. The priori information of the class label enables the supervised or semi-supervised methods [33], [34] to achieve better classification performance than unsupervised methods [35]. However, the acquisition of labeled samples is a difficult task and the requirement of labeled samples makes the supervised or semi-supervised methods incapable in some applications, such as anomaly detection, target detection and noisy band removal. Therefore, in this paper, we mainly focus on the problems of unsupervised band selection and evaluate band selection in extensive hyperspectral image applications.

To search and optimize the selection criterion, an effective search strategy is necessary. Therefore, the existing unsupervised band selection methods can be further categorized based on the search strategies they employ. Recently, many search strategies [25], [36] have been proposed and achieved considerable progresses [37], [38] in band selection, such as the ranking-based methods [39], clustering-based methods [40], [31], greedy-based methods [41], [42] and evolutionarybased methods [37], [38]. However, the performances of these methods are still far from satisfying. Most of these methods select bands by assigning a single score for one property of the band combination and fail to capture the latent structure between spectral bands in the high-dimensional band space, which are more likely to generate disordered, or insignificant band subsets by tackling bands individually [37], [42]. In fact, due to the spatial complexity of HSIs, many structures between spectral bands may be lost in selection criterion by simply assigning a single score for the band combination. Besides, the search strategies used in the aforementioned methods are inefficient when multiple graphs are introduced to capture the multiple structures in band selection. This is because the existing search strategies are almost designed on one single selected score [37], [38].

To address the aforementioned problems, a multigraph determinantal point process (MDPP) model is proposed by discovering a structure and diverse band subset from a graph: with bands as nodes and edges indicating the similarity between different bands, as shown in Fig. 1. MDPP is a graph-based method by first generating multiple graphs to uncover the latent structure of high-dimensional bands and then using a search strategy to efficiently select the most significant subset of bands. 1) Graph-based methods provide a powerful way to exploit the underlying structure between spectral bands and show great success in hyperspectral image [43]. However, in traditional graph methods, the complex structure or affinity between high-dimensional spectral bands is only represented by a single affinity value [44]. There is significant information loss from the original data space [44], especially for hyperspectral data: the dimension of spectral bands is much larger than the number of nodes (or bands). To represent the affinity between every pair of bands sufficiently, multiple graphs are constructed and capture the multiple structure in the high-dimensional band space. Multiple graphs are constructed by first partitioning the high-dimensional HSI space into several mutually independent spatial subspaces, and then generating a different affinity matrix from each independent spatial subspace. 2) After generating multiple graphs, the following problem is to develop an efficient search strategy that can find a diverse band combination. As an elegant probabilistic model, determinantal point process (DPP) [45] offers an efficient search strategy for subset selection tasks, such as information retrieval [46], document summarization [47] and video summarization. In band selection task, the informative and discriminative bands are selected to represent the whole HSI without any redundancies [28]. Due to elegant probabilistic theory arisen in quantum physics, DPP offers a powerful tool to select the informative and discriminative bands where the high-quality and diverse subsets have the highest probability [46]. However, existing DPP methods have a fatal modeling flaw if applied to multiple graphs: they fail to handle multiple view inherent structures. That is, when a standard DPP is designed on one single graph, the power of modeling multiple complex dependencies between bands is limited. To overcome the deficiency of a standard DPP, Mixture determinantal point process (Mix-DPP) is proposed to represent multiple dependencies in generated multiple graphs and efficiently search optimal band combination. Mix-DPP offers a feasible strategy to search desired band combination from multiple graphs.
The main contributions of this paper would be summarized as follows:

1) Band selection is formulated as a graph problem, where each node corresponds to a band and each edge (or affinity value) represents a relationship between bands whose semantics depend on different measure functions. A path in the graph is viewed as a potential subset and the band selection task is to find a diverse path that covers the most important bands as much as possible. To the best of our knowledge, there is no other work in regard of exploiting graph model in hyperspectral band selection.

2) Multiple graphs are designed to capture the effective and intrinsic relationships between hyperspectral bands (Section III-A). Although a single graph could be directly used as a representation, this model often goes with unacceptable information loss due to the high-dimensional descriptor of each band. In this paper, we define multiple graphs by exploiting the multiple independent land cover of HSI.

3) Determinantal point process is first introduced to hyperspectral image band selection (Section III-B) and Mix-DPP is proposed to model the multiple dependencies in the proposed multiple graphs (Section III-C). Compared with the conventional greedy based or heuristic based methods, DPP is an elegant probabilistic model of negative correlations, assigns higher probability to sets of bands that are diverse, and offers an efficient strategy for selecting a diverse subset. The efficient strategy for selecting diverse subset has been studied extensively in quantum physics and random matrix theory [45]. Furthermore, the proposed Mix-DPP method overcomes the deficiency of the standard DPP, which only captures one relationship between high-dimensional bands.

4) Extensive empirical studies with four publicly available data sets are conducted on three important applications, such as hyperspectral classification [48], anomaly detection [49], and target detection [50] (Section IV). In most cases, band selection methods are proposed for classification and the selection results are evaluated by classification accuracy [25], [26], [27]. Compared with existing methods, the proposed band selection method can be generally applied to many remote sensing fields.

The organization of this paper is as follows. After reviewing related work in Section II, the proposed method is specifically described in Section III. Section IV presents the extensive experiments on three important applications and Section V concludes the paper.

div.head: II. RELATED WORK
div.p: Band Selection: Band selection methods [51], [40], [52], [53], [54], [55], [56] try to seek the most discriminative band subset by supervised selection criteria [53], [54], [55], [56] or seek the most informative band subset [51], [40], [52] by unsupervised selection criteria. Based on these criteria (in a sense of defining an appropriate measure function), an efficient search strategy is used to find the ideal band combination. Further more, based on the search strategies they employ, band selection methods can be roughly categorized into four groups: ranking-based methods [39], [57], clusteringbased methods [40], [31], greedy-based methods [41], [42] and evolutionary-based methods [37], [38], [58]. The rankingbased methods search the desired subset by selecting the topranked bands in the sorted sequence. The importance of each band is quantified by a selection criterion such as mutual information [59], constrained band selection (CBS) [39], and maximum-variance principal component analysis (MVPCA) [60]. Alternatively, the clustering-based methods [40], [31] firstly partition the bands into disjoint clusters (clusters) and then chose the centroid of each cluster to form the selected subset. Due to the randomly initial centroid of clustering, the selected bands in the clustering-based methods may be unstable. Greedy methods decouple the NP-hard combinatorial problem by greedy hill climbing and iteratively evaluating a candidate bands subset. If the new candidate subset is an improvement over the old one, modify the subset, such as sequential forward selection (SFS) [41] and sequential backward selection (SBS) [42]. SFS begins with an empty candidate set and then gradually augments one band, while SBS starts with a full candidate set and then sequentially removes one band at each step. In evolutionary methods, the ideal solutions are gradually toward by various evolutionary computation strategies, such as genetic, immune clonal selection [37], and particle swarm optimization (PSO) [38].

Determinantal point process: Determinantal point process has obtained great successes for modeling diversity in application such as search and ranking, document summarization [46], news headline displaying [61], pose estimation [62], and video summarization [63]. DPP offers a promising tool for modeling diversity in subset selection, giving rise to its extensively study in mathematicians. Recently, many variants of DPP are proposed such as k-sequential determinantal point process (KDPP) [64], sequential determinantal point process (seqDPP) [63], and structured DPP (SDPP) [62].

div.head: III. PROPOSED MODEL
div.p: This section details the proposed MDPP for unsupervised band selection. The proposed graph framework for representing band selection is summarized in Fig. 2. In this framework, the edge between nodes (bands) is the most crucial component for its ability to capture the relationship between bands. Besides, it is found that using a single graph for band selection is not acceptable. In practice, a multiple graphs model is designed, which exploits the multiple independent views (subspaces) of land cover to effectively represent relationships between bands. Then, a Mix-DPP is proposed to efficiently find the diverse band combinations from perhaps billions of candidates.

div.head: A. Multiple Graphs
div.p: Generally, a hyperspectral image is denoted as H = [h 1 , h 2 , h 3 , ..., h l ] ∈ R n×l , where h i ∈ R n is the ith spectral band with n pixels. l is the total number of spectral bands, which is almost dozens or even hundreds. We assume that HSI has been transformed into an undirected graph G = (V, E) on l vertices, where each node corresponds to a band h i and each edge represents a relationship between bands whose semantics depend on different measure functions. It is noted that a reasonable weight function is crucial to band selection, for the function measures the importance or multiplicity of bands and the relative strength of the relationships between them [28]. Formally, a path Y from the graph is defined as the indices of selected bands. Let Y = {1, 2, 3, ..., l} be a ground set of l bands, then the path of k selected bands is Y ⊆ Y.

However, when the graph model is generated , the complex relationship between each pair of bands is only represented by a single affinity value. The information from the original band space will be lost in the creation of the affinity graph. The severe obstacle exists, particularly in the condition of high dimensional band space (complex and multivariate relationship). Therefore, constructing multiple graphs to represent the original space is of prime importance. In this section, effective and efficient multiple graphs are generated to represent the relationships between hyperspectral bands.

The multiple graphs are derived by first finding multiple independent views (spatial subspaces) of the original representation and then generating a separated affinity graph for each view. Let S = {s 1 , s 2 , s 3 , ..., s n } ∈ R l×n be the n spectral signatures in a hyperspectral image, where s i ∈ R l is the ith spectral signature. S is the transposition of H: S = H T . The first step is to find several mutually independent subspaces from the original HSI. This can be achieved by spectrally clustering the spectral signatures of HSI on an affinity graph of correlation coefficient values:
div.formula: R i,j = corr(s i , s j ) = ∑ (si-si) ∑ (sj -sj ) √ ∑ (si-si) 2 ∑ (sj -sj ) 2 , ,(1)
div.p: where R i,j denotes dependence between two spectral signatures s i and s j . As the most familiar independence measure, Eq. 1 is efficient and powerful enough to capture the dependence between each pair of spectral signatures. The second step is to perform spectral clustering [65] on R and find m disjoint clusters {C 1 , C 2 , C 3 , ...C m }. The choice of parameter m will affect the constructed multiple graphs, which is discussed in experiments below. Furthermore, the clusters should satisfy the following conditions: (1)

.., m. After this spectral clustering, it is possible to find m separated subspaces of the original spectral signature space according to each cluster. For each cluster C d , the ith element of subspace is denoted as:
div.formula: F d (s i ) = { s i , if s i ∈ C d 0, otherwise , (2
div.p: where F d is a function that maps S to the dth subspace.
Let
div.formula: T d = F d (S) ∈ R l×n d denote
L d = K (T d ) , (3
div.p: where K is the kernel function, and penalizes the relationship between different bands. The effect of kernel choice is an interesting avenue of research, which is outside the scope of this paper. Therefore, the efficient linear kernel K(S) = S ′ S is chosen in each subspace for simplicity.

Having obtained the multiple graphs, the problem is to find a desired path (or selected bands subset) to represent the whole graph without losing effectiveness. In this paper, a probabilistic model (Mix-DPP) is developed to explain the diverse and informative candidate band combinations (or subsets, or paths). Specially, a high probability path under the model should include bands that are both diverse and informative. However, finding the desired band combination from perhaps billions (2 l ) of candidates is a daunting problem. Arising in quantum physics and random matrix theory, DPP offers a promising inspiration for this problem. Due to its notable property in finding diverse subset, DPP can capture the negative correlation between bands and offer efficient algorithms to find diverse band combination from HSI. Some backgrounds are introduced in the next section.

div.head: B. Determinantal Point Process
div.p: The DPP was first proposed in quantum physics and random matrix theory, and stated two particles that cannot occupy the same quantum state simultaneously [45]. This notion of exclusion makes DPP an appealing model for subset selection problems, due to its property in modeling diverse subsets. In the basic form, DPP is a probability measure on all subsets of Y. The probability of a candidate band combination Y is distributed according to:
div.formula: P (Y ⊂ Y) = det(L Y ) det(L + I) , (4
div.p: where l ×l positive semidefinite matrix L is one of the affinity matrices computed from the multiple graphs. I is the l × l identity matrix and
div.formula: L Y ≡ [L ij ] i,j∈Y is a sub-matrix with entries selected by elements of Y . If Y = {i} is a singleton, then L Y is a scalar: L Y = [L ii ],(5)
div.p: which means the diagonal of L gives the probabilities of one single band. If Y = {i, j} is a two element set, we can write
div.formula: L Y = [ L ii L ij L ji L jj ] . (6)
div.p: Here, L Y is a 2 × 2 matrix whose diagonal elements L ii are the probabilities of selecting individual ith band and offdiagonal elements L jj expresses the interaction costs between two bands h i and h j . Thus, the corresponding probability of this subset is:
div.formula: P (i, j) ∝ L ii L jj -L 2 ij , (7
div.p: where L ij determines the orthotropic correlations between bands i and j. If bands i and j have similar spatial structure, L ij will be large and the probability of selecting bands i and j together is less than that of selecting either one of them alone. In two extreme cases, the probability of selecting two "perfectly similar" bands is 0 (L ii = L jj = L ij ), and the probability of selecting two diverse bands is maximum (L ij = 0). More details about DPP's appealing property can be found in the excellent tutorials [45]. Despite its success in document summarization [46] and video summarization [63], a direct application of DPP to band selection is problematic: 1) In standard DPP, the number of selected bands is automatically determined by the initially selected eigenvectors [45]. This is a valuable property in some instances. However, for band selection, we tend to select bands of fixed number for help in varying the performance at different number of bands or selecting bands based on small setting number. For this reason, the standard DPP is incapable of band selection. 2) The standard DPP is designed on one single graph, while limiting the power of modeling multiple complex dependencies bwtween bands. An extension of DPP is developed to overcome those limitations in the following section.

div.head: C. Multigraph Determinantal Point Process (MDPP)
div.p: In this section, the extension of DPP is described for band selection. Inspired by the limitations of standard DPP, three components for band selection are described in this section: 1) KDPP proposed by Alex Kulesza and Ben Taskar [64] can handle the first limit by conditioning a DPP on the number of selected bands. 2) A mix probabilistic model-the mix determinantal point process (Mix-DPP)-is proposed to select diverse band subset from multiple graphs. 3) An inference algorithm is capable of selecting bands from multiple graphs.

KDPP: KDPP [64] is a probability by conditioning a standard DPP on the number of selected bands k. In this case, KDPP sacrifices the ability to distinguish selection bands of varying number, but gains additional flexibility in selecting bands of fixed number k. In practice, this can be a worthwhile tradeoff. Formally, the conditional probability is:
div.formula: P k (Y ) = det(L Y ) ∑ |Y |=k det(L Y ) , (8
div.p: where the number of selected bands is: |Y | = k. Compared with the standard DPP, the only changes are the restriction on the number of selected bands and the normalized denominator. In a DPP, every k band combination Y competes with all other candidates of Y, while in a KDPP it only competes with bands of the same number. This subtle change has significant implications. See [45] for details.

div.head: Mix-DPP:
div.p: The DPP or KDPP, as previously described, is a powerful tool for modeling diverse band selection. However, a direct application of DPP to our multiple graphs is problematic. The standard DPP is designed on one single positive semidefinite matrix L Y , or an affinity matrix in a single graph. A simple solution is to group KDPPs together into a mix probabilistic model.
Given a set [L 1 , L 2 , L 3 , ...L m ] of available affinity matrices, we define the combination model
div.formula: P k α (Y ) = m ∑ d=1 α d P k L d , (9
div.p: where P k L d is the probability of the dth graph and
div.formula: m ∑ d=1 α d = 1.
div.p: In this paper, α d is defined as a "quality" probability, which is in proportion to the size of the dth graph:
div.formula: α d = n d m ∑ d=1 n d , (10
div.p: where n d is the number of spectral signatures from the dth subspace T d . Calculate the dth subspace:
div.formula: T d ← F d (S) 6)
div.p: Calculate the dth affinity graph:
div.formula: L d ← T T d T d 7)
div.p: Eigenvector/value pairs {(
div.formula: v d i , λ d i )} l i=1 of L d 8) end for 9) J ← ∅ 10) for i = l...1 do 11) if u ∼ U [0, 1] < m ∑ d=1 α d λ d i e d k-1,l-1 e d k,l then 12) J ← J ∪ {i} 13) k ← k -1 14) if k = 0 then 15)break
19) V ← {v i } i∈J 20) Y ← ∅ 21) while |V | > 0 do 22) Select i from Y with P r(i) = m ∑ d=1 α d 1 |V d | ∑ v∈V d ( v T e i )2
div.p: 23) Y ← Y ∪ i 24) V ← V ⊥ an orthonormal basis for the subspace of V orthogonal to e i 25) end while Inference: One of the primary advantages of DPP is that its inference can be performed in polynomial time. Now we discuss how to sample a configuration Y from the proposed MDPP. An efficient algorithm for sampling structures from an KDPP is derived in [64]. As proved in [64], a KDPP is a mixture of elementary DPPs:
div.formula: P k L d = 1 e d k,l ∑ |J|=k P V J ∏ i∈J λ d i , (11
div.p: where
div.formula: P VJ is called elementary DPP if eigenvalue λ d i of L d is in {0, 1}. V J
div.p: is a set of orthonormal vectors and J ⊂ {1, 2, 3...l}. e d k,l is a shorthand for:
div.formula: e d k,l = e k ( λ d 1 , λ d 2 , ...λ d l ) = ∑ |J|=k ∏ i∈J λ d i . (12
div.p: Substituting Eq. 11 back into Eq. 9, we get
div.formula: P k α (i) = m ∑ d=1 α d 1 e d k,l ∑ |J|=k P V J ∏ i∈J λ d i = m ∑ d=1 ∑ |J|=k P VJ α d 1 e d k,l ∏ i∈J λ d i ,(13)
div.p: Therefore, a MDPP is also a mixture of elementary DPPs, and it gives weight to those of different graphs. It has been proved in [64] that an algorithm sampling from a KDPP has two main loops. First selecting a subset of the eigenvector from
div.formula: L d depending on λ d i e d k-1,l-1 e d k,l
div.p: and then output Y based on the probability of selecting the ith band1
div.formula: |V d | ∑ v∈V d ( v T e i ) 2
div.p: . Full proofs of the sampling algorithm see [45]. Furthermore, the corresponding probabilities in MDPP are:
div.formula: m ∑ d=1 α d λ d i e d k-1,l-1 e d k,l , (14
) m ∑ d=1 α d 1 |V d | ∑ v∈V d ( v T e i )2 . (15
div.p: Finally, the desired index of selected bands can be estimated by sampling from Eq. 9. The implementation details of the proposed method are summarized in Algorithm 1.

Computational [66]. However, many methods have been proposed to address the computational difficulties of spectral clustering and shorten computational time. The second most time-consuming step is sampling from a Mix-DPP, requiring O ( lk3 m ) time. If k is large, Mix-DPP can encounter a cube resource bottleneck, but for most applications we do not want high number of selected bands k and the number l is almost dozens or hundreds. Therefore, from an overall perspective, the proposed method can guarantee selecting bands in acceptable computational time.

div.head: IV. EXPERIMENTS
div.p: In this section, three subsections are presented to verify the effectiveness of the proposed method. 1) We first describe experimental data sets and competitors in Subsection IV-A.

2) Then we conduct a thorough study on the main parameters of the proposed method in Subsection IV-B. 3) In Subsection IV-C, we conduct the experiments on three applications to demonstrate the benefits of the proposed method for band selection in details and compare it with the state-of-the-art methods.

div.head: A. Data Sets and Competitors
div.p: Data Sets: To demonstrate the capability of the proposed method for band selection, four widely used data sets are employed in experiments.

Indian Pines scene: The first data set is a well-known AVIRIS data collected at Indian Pines scene 1 whose size is 145 × 145 × 220. Only 206 bands are used in the experiment after removing the bands from 150-163 which are disturbed by the atmospheric and water. Moreover, a classification method is employed on this data set after band selection to further verify the effectiveness of the proposed method.

Pavia University scene: The second data set is Pavia University scene 2 , it is used in classified experiment to demonstrate the capability of the proposed method for band selection. This image contains 610 × 340 pixels and 103 spectral bands with 12 non-informational bands discarded.

Salinas scene: The third data set is Salinas scene 3 which is gathered by the 224-band AVIRIS system. The data consists of 512217 pixels with spectral coverage within 0.4-2.5um, and comprises vegetables, bare soils, and vineyard fields with spatial resolution of 3.7 m. Due to water vapor absorption and low SNR, bands 108-112, 154-167, and 224 are removed. Thus, a total of 204 valid bands are used in the experiments.

Montana scene: The forth data set 4 used in experiments is collected by the HyMap sensor in July 2006 around the small town of Cooke City, Montana, USA. The data set has a spatial size of 800 × 280 with 126 bands. To verify the effectiveness of the proposed method, this data set is used for hyperspectral anomaly detection and hyperspectral target detection after band selection. A part of size 400×280×126 is selected from the original image, which includes four targets fabric panels.

Competitors: To verify the performance of the proposed framework, comprehensive and comparative experiments are conducted on eight representative unsupervised band selection methods: constrained energy minimization-band correlation minimization (CEM-BCM), constrained energy minimizationband correlation constraint (CEM-BCC), linearly constrained minimum variance-band correlation minimization (LCMV-BCM), linearly constrained minimum variance-band correlation constraint (LCMV-BCC), sequential forward selection (SFS), volume gradient band selection (VGBS), particle swarm optimization (PSO) [38] and multi-task sparsity pursuit (MTSP) [37]. The details of these approaches are as follows:

1) Ranking-based Methods. As a ranking-based method, constrained band selection (CBS) [39] selects bands by imposing constrained band correlation and dependence minimization in two different strategies: constrained energy minimization (CEM) and linearly constrained minimum variance (LCMV). In these two implementations, four specific criteria are employed: band correlation minimization (BCM), band correlation constraint (BCC), band dependence minimization (BDM), and band dependence constraint (BDC). Since the criteria BCM and BDM yield the identical bands for both the CEM and the LCMV, we just use CEM-BCM and LCMV-BCM in this paper. Similarly, it is true for BCC and BDC which also produce the identical bands for the CEM and the LCMV. There are four different methods in CBS methods including CEM-BCM, CEM-BCC, LCMV-BCM, and LCMV-BCC. The CBS based methods can be considered as the classical band selection methods.

2) Greedy-based Methods. Two popular greedy-based methods are used: sequential forward selection (SFS) [38] and volume gradient band selection (VGBS) [27]. VGBS can be classified as a sequential backward selection (SBS). Both methods are proposed to sequential feature selection and have been demonstrated effectiveness in band selection [25]. The selection criterion in SFS is minimum estimated abundance covariance (MEAC) [25] which is used to compute score over all feasible feature subsets. Recently, it is proved that MEAC is a simple but effective criterion and does not need training samples [25]. The selection criterion in VGBS is maximum ellipsoid volume (MEV) [27] which is used to choose the subset of bands with the maximum entropy. Therefore, these two greedy-based methods are also promising band selection methods.

3) Evolutionary-based Methods. Evolutionary-based methods have demonstrated efficient in band selection for its global searching capability. In this paper, two latest evolutionary methods are selected: particle swarm optimization (PSO) [38] and multi-task sparsity pursuit (MTSP) [37], which can generally achieve the state-of-the-art performances. PSO mimics swarm behavior in birds flocking to guide particles in searching for a global optimal solution, while MTSP uses immune clonal strategy to search candidate hyperspectral band combinations. Both methods are the latest methods of hyperspectral band selection. 1) Parameter Determination: In this subsection, the impact of parameters is evaluated on Indian Pines scene. We evaluate the performance of band selection on two applications: hyperspectral classification and noisy band removal. Both produced classification results and selected clear bands are analyzed by classification accuracy and retrieved precision, respectively. In hyperspectral classification, four classifiers are used to provide a goal-independent evaluation [67], such as classification and regression trees (CART) [68], support vector machine (SVM) [69], linear discriminant analysis (LDA) [70] and k-nearest neighborhood (KNN) [71]. In noisy band removal, 206 bands are defined as informative bands, while the noised bands from 150-163 are removed.

div.head: B. Experimental Setting
div.p: The parameters of the proposed method can be clearly delineated in Algorithm 1: the number of selected bands k and the number of spectral subspaces m. The former parameter k controls the number of selected bands, which is discussed in the following various experiments. Therefore, we only tune the latter parameter m in this section. The evaluation is carried out by calculating m in the range of 1, 2, 3, ...30 when the parameter k is fixed to the default value: k = 50. Experimental results for various m are shown in Fig. 3. It is observed that with the increase of the number of spectral subspaces m, the performance increases slightly and then saturates. When m is bigger than 10 (m ≥ 10), the classification accuracy will approximate to the best. However, retrieved precision only receives the best performance when m = 1, 14, 20, 26, 29 and a large m will increase the computational complexity. Therefore, m = 20 offers a good tradeoff between efficiency and efficacy. 2) Approximation Analysis: Although there are some random operations in Algorithm 1 such as spectral clustering (step 2) and sampling inference (steps 11 and 22), the solution of the proposed method is stable. To show the robustness and stableness of the proposed method, we present two different experiments on Indian Pines scene: hyperspectral classification in 50 individual runs and the visualization of selected bands in 500 individual runs.

In hyperspectral classification, four classifiers are used to provide a goal-independent evaluation [67] and the number of selected band is 5. In visualization, the number of selected band is 2 and 500 individual solutions are presented in a twodimensional visualization. Experimental results are shown in Fig. 4. It is observed from Fig. 4(a) that the performances of four classifiers are stable in 50 individual runs. The visualization in Fig. 4(b) clearly shows that most solutions are centralized while only few solutions are scattered. The most centralized solutions indicate that the solution of the proposed is stable, while the few scattered solutions indicate that the solution of the proposed method is robustness and allows us to effectively avoid getting stuck in local minima. Therefore, the selected bands determined by the proposed method are overall consistent with the optimal solution.

div.head: C. Hyperspectral Applications
div.p: In this subsection, three applications are presented to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method when comparing with the state-of-the-art methods.

1) Hyperspectral Classification: In this section, a hyperspectral classification is implemented on three data sets to evaluate the performance of band selection. To this end, four widely used classification methods are adopted to compare the applicability of each band selection method, including classification and regression trees (CART) [68], support vector machine (SVM) [69], linear discriminant analysis (LDA) [70] and k-nearest neighborhood (KNN) [71]. To obtain reliable results, we repeat classification 10 times and create 10 train/test splits. For the sake of comparison, we present two evaluations: accuracy curve and average accuracy. The accuracy curve plots classification accuracy versus the number of selected bands k, while the average accuracy is denoted as average of the classification accuracy in all the employed k.

The first data used for classification is Indian Pines scene, which contains 16 classes. Moreover, the numbers of training and test samples for each category are shown in Table I. The comparative accuracy curves produced by CART, SVM, LDA, and KNN are illustrated in Fig. 5(a)-5(d), respectively. The average values are listed in Table 5(a). As shown in Fig. 5(a) and Fig. 5(b), the bands selected by proposed method show comparable classification performance to the competitors on the employed classifiers CART and LDA. However, as shown in Fig. 5(c) and Fig. 5(d), if SVM or KNN is employed, the accuracy curves can no longer provide clues discriminative enough to support comparative analysis. In such case, the average of the four classification accuracies will be the more important indicator. The corresponding results are demonstrated in the last column of Table II. It is manifested that the proposed method clearly dominates all the other methods.

The second data used for classification is Pavia University scene, which contains 9 classes. Moreover, the numbers of training and test samples for each category are shown in Table III. The comparison results are shown in Fig. 6 with the same form as in Fig. 5. As seen in Fig. 6, the bands selected by the proposed method show comparable classification performance on the employed classifiers SVM and LDA. However, as presented in Fig. 6(a) and Fig. 6(c), CEM-BCM slightly outperforms the proposed method when the CART and KNN classifiers are utilized. Therefore, the average of the four classification accuracies will be the more important indicator. The corresponding results are demonstrated in the last column of Table IV. As is depicted, the proposed method achieves significant superiorities in the average accuracy.

The third data used for classification is Salinas scene, which contains 16 classes. Moreover, the numbers of training and test samples for each category are shown in Table V. The comparative accuracy curves produced by CART, SVM, LDA, and KNN are illustrated in Fig. 7(a)-7(d), respectively. This figure indicates that the proposed method outperforms the competitors when classifiers SVM and LDA are employed. Moreover, the proposed method performs the best classification over all the number of selected bands when the classifier SVM is employed. With respect to the number of selected bands, the proposed method always achieves the comparable classification accuracy when the four classifiers are employed. Furthermore, to thoroughly evaluate the generalized strength of the proposed method, the average accuracies of the four classification are listed in Table VI. As shown in Table VI, the bands selected by proposed method show comparable classification performance to the competitors on all the employed classifiers.

From the experimental results, we can observe that the proposed method achieves generalized power over different classifiers. Compared with CBS methods, greedy methods, and evolutionary methods, the proposed method produces better classification results. Several observations can be made from the results shown in Table II, Table IV most employed classifiers. Also, the best statistical results are attained by the proposed method in terms of average value. Thus, it can be inferred that the proposed method has the ability to select the diverse band combinations in a greater probability for hyperspectral classification.

div.head: 2) Hyperspectral Anomaly Detection:
div.p: To demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method, an anomaly detection is presented on Montana scene. We use the widely used reed-xiaoli detector (RXD) [72] to detect abnormal targets after band selection. To quantitatively evaluate the detection performance, three evaluations are presented: receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves, the corresponding area under the curves (AUCs) and false alarm rate (FAR) at 0.052 detection rate (DR) [73]. Furthermore, another purpose of this experiment is to find whether the abnormal targets could be found in a small number of selected bands. Thus, we set the numbers of selected bands from 1 to 20.

Fig. 8 shows the AUC and FAR at a DR of 5.2 percent with various numbers of selected bands k. The average values are listed in Table VII. To give detailed contrast result, four specified numbers of selected bands k are selected to show the corresponding ROC in Fig. 9. As seen in Fig. 8, when RXD is used, the proposed method result in a promising detection performance across all the number k. Moreover, in Table VII, the proposed method achieves significant superiorities in AUC, which further proves the effectiveness of the proposed method. In particular, when the number of selected bands k is relatively small, the detection performance of the proposed method is always the best. That is, the proposed MDPP method is powerful enough to find the diverse set of bands, even though the number of selected bands is limited. However, we can also see from Fig. 8 that detection performances for CBS methods are improving with the increase in the number of selected bands. This is consistent with the conclusion in [50]. Furthermore, when the number of selected bands is large, all the selected subsets can distinguish the anomaly in acceptable levels. We expect that the performance of anomaly detection can be greatly improved by the proposed method, since the proposed method discovers the diverse subset of bands.

div.head: 3) Hyperspectral Target Detection:
div.p: To further demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method, we present target detection on Montana scene, and use the widely used adaptive coherence estimator (ACE) [74] to produce the comparison results after bands selection. To quantitatively evaluate the detection results, we first present quantitative assessments with varied k, then investigate the optimal number of selected bands and present the ROC curves for the optimal number of selected bands k.

Quantitative assessments are presented in Fig. 10, where Fig. 10(a)-Fig. 10(d) present the AUC produced by four different targets. As observed from Fig. 10(a)-Fig. 10(d), the performances of the proposed method almost dominate the competitors on all the targets. Moreover, we present the optimal number of selected bands and the corresponding AUC in Table VIII. As can be seen, the optimal selected bands of the proposed method have both higher discriminative capability and smaller number. We also present the detection performance of 121 manual selected bands with the noisy bands removed manually. Compared with the performance of manual selected bands, all band selection methods can obtain competitive AUC values with few bands. This phenomenon demonstrates that band selection generally results in improved detection performance with smaller number of bands.

To quantitatively compare these methods, the ROC curves of four targets are presented in Fig. 11 when the optimal number of selected bands k is set. The ROC curves show that the bands selected by the proposed method have the best detection performance since it has the highest detection rate at the same false alarm rate. Compared with the proposed method, evolutionary methods have a lower detection rate, which can be ascribed to the disordered band combination without sequence constraint. The other two types of methods, namely, CBS methods and greedy methods, have very poor performance in terms of target detection. Since both methods fail to select the band combinations that can separate the target from the background. 4) Discussion: From all the aforementioned experiments, we can see that the proposed method achieves generalized power in three important hyperspectral applications. This is because that the proposed method is completely unsupervised and application-independent which are properly applied to many remote sensing applications. For the other competitors, the selected bands are always designed on hyperspectral classification. Although the selected bands of the competitors are sensitive to hyperspectral classification but are not sensitive to the other hyperspectral applications such as hyperspectral anomaly detection and hyperspectral target detection. Thus, the competitors obtain the poor performance in anomaly detection and target detection. In other words, although the competitors are effective for hyperspectral classification, they rely on the class separability, which seek the discriminative band combination. That means the generalized property of selection criterion plays a key role in general hyperspectral tasks.

In three hyperspectral applications, the performances of the proposed method are significantly better than the competitors. The reasons for the robustness of the proposed method are mainly the followings: 1) Multiple graphs model is effective for band selection, which is helpful to capture the intrinsic relationships between hyperspectral bands. 2) The diverse property of DPP is reliable enough to select the discriminative and representative band combination without any priori information of the class label. Due to this property, the proposed method can adapt to generic hyperspectral tasks. It can be seen from three hyperspectral applications that the proposed method always performs better compared with other competitors.
3) The efficiency of the search strategy ensures that the proposed method is suitable and efficient for further hyperspectral applications.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, a multigraph determinantal point process (MDPP) method is proposed to effectively find a diverse band combination that contains discriminative and informative bands for hyperspectral applications. A graph framework is used to exploit the underlying structure between different bands, and the selected bands are denoted as one diverse path through the generated affinity graph. To fully capture the underlying distribution, effective and efficient multiple graphs are generated to reveal the relationships between hyperspectral bands. Furthermore, a Mix-DPP is proposed to model the distribution over numerous possible subsets and it assigns higher probability to band combinations that are diverse. Finally, an efficient sampling algorithm is used to find the desired index of selected bands. The experimental results on four data sets indicate that the proposed method can select the discriminative and informative bands efficiently compared with other state-of -the-art methods in three extensive applications.
